awd_titl_txt: Psychological mechanisms behind organ donation decisions
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite the increase in the number of life-saving organ transplants in the last decades, organs recovered from deceased donors are not adequate to meet the increasing demand in most countries. In many cases, the possibility of organ transplantation is prevented because of the objection of the donor's family, especially when the deceased herself did not express her willingness for organ donation (OD) while alive. This project implements a broad and in-depth research program to understand behavioral and psychological mechanisms behind OD decisions. It aims to find ways to increase the percentage of organ donors and the support for policies that may increase ODs. For example, encouraging OD receivers to tell their story in the media (with identifying detail) may increase the support for OD. Likewise, providing statistical information about the average life expectancy may promote realistic thinking about death and may increase willingness to commit to OD. We believe that increasing the number of potential organ donors as well as the public awareness of this issue may help to save the lives of many that are waiting for organ transplants.

The planned research addresses three main objectives. (1) To learn about the role of the presentation of OD cases in affecting people's willingness to commit to OD (including the decision to donate the organs of a deceased relative).  (2) To examine individual differences in death anxiety (Fear of Personal Death - FPD) and in people's beliefs, to learn about their role in predicting people's decisions regarding OD issues. (3) To manipulate the factors situationally, using priming techniques (i.e., priming thoughts about religious issues, about just vs. unjust world; thoughts of tempting fate; manipulation or increasing the salience of different aspects of the FPD) to examine the influence of such manipulations on people's decisions regarding OD issues. Together, these research directions will help us to better understand the mechanisms behind OD decisions and describe how these decisions differ from other donation decisions.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Despite the growing number of life-saving organ transplants in recent decades and their increasing success rates, in most countries not enough organs are recovered from deceased donors to meet the increasing demand. In many cases, organ transplantation is prevented by the donor?s family?s refusal to permit it?particularly when the deceased person had not expressed their willingness for organ donation. The primary aim of this research was to understand the psychological underpinnings of people's decisions regarding organ donations. Specifically, we examined what motivates people to sign an organ donation commitment (a donor card), to donate the organs of a deceased family member, or to support policies that have the potential to increase the number of registered donors.

We often encounter cases of organ donation in the press or on TV. In one part of our research, we examined how might these stories affect readers. We found that reading coverage of cases that include identifying information about the receiver (saved by organ donation) increased participants? willingness to commit to organ donation themselves, to donate the organs of a deceased relative, or to support a transition to a policy that registers a person as a donor unless they actively ?opt-out?. Conversely, identifying the deceased donor induced thoughts of death rather than thoughts about saving lives, resulting in fewer participants willing to donate organs or to support policies that facilitate organ donation. We show that most of the stories that appear in the press include an identified donor rather than an identified receiver, possibly reducing organ donations.

Presentation of organ donation issues may be context-dependent, and may affect different people in different ways, depending on their individual characteristics and beliefs. Since religious attitudes have been found to be a major barrier to organ donations, we examined how the presentation of organ donation issues may affect religious versus secular people, depending on the salience of religiosity at the time of the decision. We found that the salience of religious issues reduced support for organ donations among religious participants, but increased support among the non-religious participants. These findings highlight the importance of religious-sensitive presentation of organ donation issues, and the need to adapt the message to specific populations.

Looking at differences between people who are and those who are not registered donors, we found that people who refuse to sign an organ donation commitment not only experience greater fear of death, but that their fears would become more intense after being asked to sign such a commitment. Moreover, for religious refusers, concerns about the hereafter were especially intense, which may at least partially explain their refusal.

Broader Impacts

Understanding the conscious and unconscious reasons why people refuse or agree to become potential organ donors is of great importance?both from a theoretical and from practical point of view, and in the bid to find ways to increase consent rates. Insights from the present research offer several ways of enhancing support for organ donation by persuading people to donate their own organs after death, or those of their deceased loved ones. One method is to share the story of recipients whose lives were saved by organ donation, and identifying them by name. Identifying deceased organ donors may not be a good strategy?because such presentations prompt thoughts of death, rather than of the possibility of saving lives. Furthermore, it is important to create a dialog with religious communities, in an effort to encourage religious people to join the potential organ donor pool. Thus, when appealing to families to donate the organs of their deceased loved ones it would be better to avoid talking about religious views and focus instead on positive aspects of organ donation (as an act of charity, and as a means of saving lives)?especially when the family is known to hold strong religious views. Finally, messages about organ donation should be sensitive to people?s fears, especially the fear of death. This may be done by highlighting the idea that organ donations symbolically extend the life of the deceased, by giving them the meaning of saving another. We hope that the results of the present research (coupled with future research on the psychological, religious and cultural barriers to organ donation from deceased donors) will help to overcome these obstacles, and save the lives of many people awaiting organ donation.
